conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light from a source, creating a dark area on a surface. The size and position of the shadow depend on the relative positions of the light source, the object, and the surface.
The initial scene shows four objects above the slabs, illuminated by a light source positioned at the front upper side, casting shadows A, B, C, and D on the ground behind the objects.

premise: When the light source moves backward (away from the objects), the angle between the light illuminating the object and the horizontal direction increases.
conclusion: As the light source moves backward, shadows A, B, C, and D shift forward, moving beneath the objects.

premise: When the light source moves backward (away from the objects), the angle between the light illuminating the object and the horizontal direction increases.
conclusion: As the light source moves backward, shadows A, B, C, and D become shorter and smaller.

premise: Shadows A, B, C, and D shift forward and become shorter and smaller when the light source moves backward above the objects.
conclusion: A, B, C, and D shift forward, moving beneath the objects, and become shorter and smaller.
